div.p: 1. itu notumalar varaiyum paruvattut tōḻi talaivikku aṟattoṭu nilai payappac (EV: aṟattoṭu niṟpac) colliyatu. 2. varaivu malintatū(u)mām.

1. This is what the confidante said to HER at the moment strangers had come with a marriage proposal so that she would agree to standing up to virtue (~ revealing the truth). 2. It is also what rejoices in marriage.

lg.l: amarkka ṇāmā ṉaruniṟa muḷkātu
paṇaitta pakaḻip pōkkuniṉaintu kāṉava
ṉaṇaṅkoṭu niṉṟatu malaivāṉ koḷkeṉak
kaṭavu ḷōṅkuvarai pēṇmār vēṭṭeḻuntu
kiḷaiyoṭu makiḻuṅ kuṉṟa nāṭa
ṉaṭaitarun tōṟu marumaitaṉak kuraippa
nappuṇar villā nayaṉi lōrnaṭ
paṉṉa vākuka veṉṉā
ṉolkā toḻimikap palkiṉa tūtē.
The man from a land of hills,
where the forest inhabitant, thinking of the move of [his] arrow that failed,

not piercing the vital spotTVG explains that niṟam here means the forefront of the cow, but I rather think that we have here one further instance of a special meaning of niṟam as "the vital spot" of an animal (which can be etymologically related to niṟam "breast", DEDR 3681); cf. KT 272.5. difficult [to hit] of the pretty-eyed wild cow,
rises for hunt in order to worship the god's high mountain,

saying “may the mountain, that stands with aṇaṅku, take the sky”malai vāṉ koḷka: this formulaic expression certainly is a metaphor for rain, as is confirmed by the old commentary on PN 143.1, where we find the gloss malaiyai maḻai vantu cūḻka.,
[and] rejoices with [his] relatives,
– while [we] talk to him about the difficulties whenever he arrives(?),
he does not say:
“let [this] be like the intimacy of those who have no longing”,

without uniting with us.What is supposed to be the message in this mixture of explicity and insinuation? HE does not pay heed to HER warnings and insists on making love to her, without, however, taking the consequences? And what, then, does the next line say? Whose messages (or, for that matter, messengers)? There is no reason at all to follow the kiḷavi here and think of other proposals for marriage. The topos of the tūtu is clearly connected to the exchange between HIM and HER (and it usually does not take place but is only spoken about, although there are some rare exceptions, such as KT 106).
Stay behind without weakening. The messages have become very many.
“may the mountain, that stands with aṇaṅku, [and] the sky take [it]”

“may the mountain [and] the sky take the one that stands in torment”Two additional possibilities make the thing to be given and accepted the wounded cow, which would make the whole a propitiation of the deities so that the hunt would be more successful next time.
